The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. The new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (e) and the new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (f). The credit amount for the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is based on the vehicle placed in service during the taxable year. The credit amount for a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle placed in service by the taxpayer during the taxable year is determined under paragraph (2) according to a specified table. The credit amount for a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle is determined based on the city fuel economy percentage compared to a comparable vehicle, ranging from $1,500 to $3,500. The city fuel economy of a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is determined on an E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent basis, while the comparable vehicle is determined on a gasoline gallon equivalent basis. The vehicle must be capable of operating on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend, and achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol of at least 125. The legislation aims to extend the termination date for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles to December 31, 2014. It also includes vehicles in the numeric limitation and makes conforming amendments to the existing code.
